name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
prompt:
The new generation external memory consists of an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. You have the freedom to choose any pair of indices for l and r within this constraint. It is important to note that this selection will define the segment you can work with.
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted. Consider various strategies and optimizations that may help achieve the task efficiently.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5

Output

1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. It is up to you to decide which indices to choose. Make sure you pick indices such that l is less than r.
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2.

In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the operations performed.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: List of results for each test case, where each result contains the number of operations and the details of each operation.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        operations = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, operations))
            continue
        
        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            # Find the minimum element in the unsorted part of the array
            min_index = i + array[i:].index(min(array[i:]))
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                segment_length = min_index - i + 1
                operations.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, segment_length - 1))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                array[i:min_index + 1] = array[i:min_index + 1][-1:] + array[i:min_index + 1][:-1]
        
        results.append((len(operations), operations))
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = r - l

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = a[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # Check if the array is sorted
                if a == sorted_a:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    # Input interface
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the cyclic shifts.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        # Simple strategy to sort using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_array.index(array[i])
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift
                    l = i + 1
                    r = correct_pos + 1
                    d = r - l
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    # Perform the shift
                    segment = array[l-1:r]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # We will perform a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is not necessarily optimal but will satisfy the problem constraints
        for i in range(n - 1):
            # Find the minimum element in the unsorted part of the array
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            # If the minimum element is not at the current position, perform a cyclic shift
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift from i to min_index
                # The offset is min_index - i
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                actions.append((l, r, d))
                
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = array[i:min_index + 1]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                array[i:min_index + 1] = shifted_segment
        
        # Append the result for this test case
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    index = 0
    t = int(data[index])
    index += 1
    
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        index += 1
        array = list(map(int, data[index:index + n]))
        index += n
        test_cases.append((n, array))
    
    # Call the function
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        shift_count = 0
        
        while array != sorted_array and shift_count < n:
            for l in range(n):
                for r in range(l + 1, n):
                    segment = array[l:r+1]
                    for d in range(1, r - l + 1):
                        shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                        new_array = array[:l] + shifted_segment + array[r+1:]
                        if new_array == sorted_array:
                            actions.append((l + 1, r + 1, d))
                            array = new_array
                            shift_count += 1
                            break
                    if array == sorted_array:
                        break
                if array == sorted_array:
                    break
        
        results.append((shift_count, actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface

## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the cyclic shift actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue
        
        # We will perform cyclic shifts until the array is sorted or n shifts are done
        for _ in range(n):
            if array == sorted_array:
                break
            
            # Find the first unsorted segment
            for l in range(n - 1):
                if array[l] > array[l + 1]:
                    break
            
            # Find the right boundary of the unsorted segment
            for r in range(l + 1, n):
                if array[r] < array[r - 1]:
                    break
            else:
                r = n
            
            # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment [l, r]
            d = 1  # We choose an offset of 1 for simplicity
            segment = array[l:r]
            shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
            array[l:r] = shifted_segment
            
            actions.append((l + 1, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface

from typing import List
## main.py

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: list[tuple[int, list[int]]]) -> list[tuple[int, list[tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        operations = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, operations))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                a[i:r] = a[i+d:r] + a[i:i+d]
                operations.append((l, r, d))
        
        results.append((len(operations), operations))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(data[index])
        a = list(map(int, data[index + 1].split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))
        index += 2

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of operations and their details.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of operations and a list of operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        operations = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, operations))
            continue

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if array == sorted_array:
                break

            # Find the first unsorted segment
            for l in range(n - 1):
                if array[l] > array[l + 1]:
                    break

            # Find the end of the unsorted segment
            for r in range(l + 1, n):
                if array[r] < array[r - 1]:
                    break
            else:
                r = n

            # Perform a cyclic shift on the segment
            d = 1  # Arbitrary offset, can be adjusted
            segment = array[l:r]
            shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
            array[l:r] = shifted_segment
            operations.append((l + 1, r, d))

        results.append((len(operations), operations))

    return results

# Input interface

    test_cases = []

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: For each test case, returns the number of shifts and the details of each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        if a == sorted_a:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        # Simple strategy: perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = a.index(sorted_a[i], i)
                if correct_pos != i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift
                    l = i + 1
                    r = correct_pos + 1
                    d = 1
                    a[l-1:r] = a[l-1+1:r] + a[l-1:l-1+1]
                    actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and the details of each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_a = sorted(a)

        # Perform cyclic shifts to sort the array
        for i in range(n):
            if a[i] != sorted_a[i]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                d = r - l

                # Perform the cyclic shift
                segment = a[l-1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                a[l-1:r] = shifted_segment

                # Record the action
                actions.append((l, r, d))

                # Check if the array is sorted
                if a == sorted_a:
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface

# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within a segment without changing the overall length of the array.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing a series of cyclic shifts. The goal is to achieve a sorted array using no more than n cyclic shifts.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means that the solution must sort the array within n operations.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0.
3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements closer to their correct positions.
4. Use list slicing to perform cyclic shifts on identified segments.
5. Keep track of each operation (l, r, d) and ensure the number of operations does not exceed n.
6. Output the number of operations and the details of each operation for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Test case 1: [1, 1, 1, 1] = 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no operations are needed.

    Test case 2: [5, 4, 3, 2, 1] = 5
    Explanation: The array is in reverse order, requiring multiple shifts to sort. Each element needs to be moved to its correct position.

    Test case 3: [2, 3, 1] = 1
    Explanation: A single shift can sort this small array by moving '1' to the front.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted and performing necessary shifts will handle these cases effectively.

    'arbitrary'
    Explanation: The term 'arbitrary' in this context means that you can choose any indices l and r within the constraints, and any offset d within the allowed range for each operation.

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0.
3. If not sorted, perform cyclic shifts:
   - Identify segments that need to be shifted to sort the array.
   - For each segment, determine the appropriate l, r, and d values.
   - Apply the cyclic shift using list slicing.
   - Record each operation.
4. Ensure that the total number of operations does not exceed n.
5. Output the number of operations and their details for each test case.

We will implement a function to sort arrays using cyclic shifts. The function will iterate over the array, identify segments that need to be shifted, and perform the necessary cyclic shifts to sort the array. We will use a simple approach that ensures the number of shifts does not exceed the length of the array. The solution will handle multiple test cases efficiently and provide output in the specified format.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within a segment without changing the overall size of the array.

    'sort using cyclic shifts'
    Explanation: The task is to sort the array by performing cyclic shifts on segments of the array. The number of shifts should not exceed the length of the array.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n cyclic shifts': The number of cyclic shifts performed should be less than or equal to the length of the array.
    '1 ≤ l < r ≤ n': The indices l and r define the segment boundaries and must satisfy this inequality.
    '1 ≤ d ≤ r - l': The offset d for the cyclic shift must be within this range.

# [degree adverb] 
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and an empty sequence.
3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements closer to their sorted positions.
4. For each identified segment, perform a cyclic shift by choosing appropriate l, r, and d values.
5. Ensure that the number of shifts does not exceed n.
6. Output the number of shifts k and the details of each shift in the format "l r d".

# [edge case] 
    Test case with already sorted array: 
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4] 
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case with minimum size array:
    Input: [2, 1]
    Output: 1
    Explanation: A single shift of the entire array will sort it.

    Test case with all identical elements:
    Input: [3, 3, 3]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted as all elements are identical.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted and handling minimum size arrays will naturally cover these scenarios.
examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
